speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: SCENE III. The Grecian camp. Before Achilles' tent.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Enter THERSITES, solus

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: How now, Thersites! what lost in the labyrinth of

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: thy fury! Shall the elephant Ajax carry it thus? He

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: beats me, and I rail at him: O, worthy satisfaction!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: would it were otherwise; that I could beat him,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: whilst he railed at me. 'Sfoot, I'll learn to

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: conjure and raise devils, but I'll see some issue of

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: my spiteful execrations. Then there's Achilles, a

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: rare enginer! If Troy be not taken till these two

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: undermine it, the walls will stand till they fall of

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: themselves. O thou great thunder-darter of Olympus,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: forget that thou art Jove, the king of gods and,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Mercury, lose all the serpentine craft of thy

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: caduceus, if ye take not that little, little less

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: than little wit from them that they have! which

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: short-armed ignorance itself knows is so abundant

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: scarce, it will not in circumvention deliver a fly

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: from a spider, without drawing their massy irons and

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: cutting the web. After this, the vengeance on the

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: whole camp! or rather, the bone-ache! for that,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: methinks, is the curse dependent on those that war

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: for a placket. I have said my prayers and devil Envy

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: say Amen. What ho! my Lord Achilles!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter PATROCLUS

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Who's there? Thersites! Good Thersites, come in and rail.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: If I could have remembered a gilt counterfeit, thou

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: wouldst not have slipped out of my contemplation: but

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: it is no matter; thyself upon thyself! The common

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: curse of mankind, folly and ignorance, be thine in

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: great revenue! heaven bless thee from a tutor, and

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: discipline come not near thee! Let thy blood be thy

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: direction till thy death! then if she that lays thee

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: out says thou art a fair corse, I'll be sworn and

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: sworn upon't she never shrouded any but lazars.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Amen. Where's Achilles?

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: What, art thou devout? wast thou in prayer?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Ay: the heavens hear me!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter ACHILLES

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Who's there?

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Thersites, my lord.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Where, where? Art thou come? why, my cheese, my

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: digestion, why hast thou not served thyself in to

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: my table so many meals? Come, what's Agamemnon?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Thy commander, Achilles. Then tell me, Patroclus,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: what's Achilles?

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Thy lord, Thersites: then tell me, I pray thee,

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: what's thyself?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Thy knower, Patroclus: then tell me, Patroclus,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: what art thou?

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Thou mayst tell that knowest.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: O, tell, tell.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: I'll decline the whole question. Agamemnon commands

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Achilles; Achilles is my lord; I am Patroclus'

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: knower, and Patroclus is a fool.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: You rascal!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Peace, fool! I have not done.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: He is a privileged man. Proceed, Thersites.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Agamemnon is a fool; Achilles is a fool; Thersites

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: is a fool, and, as aforesaid, Patroclus is a fool.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Derive this; come.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Agamemnon is a fool to offer to command Achilles;

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Achilles is a fool to be commanded of Agamemnon;

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Thersites is a fool to serve such a fool, and

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Patroclus is a fool positive.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Why am I a fool?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Make that demand of the prover. It suffices me thou

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: art. Look you, who comes here?

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Patroclus, I'll speak with nobody.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Come in with me, Thersites.

speaker: ACHILLES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Here is such patchery, such juggling and such

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: knavery! all the argument is a cuckold and a

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: whore; a good quarrel to draw emulous factions

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: and bleed to death upon. Now, the dry serpigo on

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: the subject! and war and lechery confound all!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter AGAMEMNON, ULYSSES, NESTOR, DIOMEDES, and AJAX

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Where is Achilles?

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Within his tent; but ill disposed, my lord.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Let it be known to him that we are here.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: He shent our messengers; and we lay by

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Our appertainments, visiting of him:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Let him be told so; lest perchance he think

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We dare not move the question of our place,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Or know not what we are.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: I shall say so to him.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: We saw him at the opening of his tent:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He is not sick.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Yes, lion-sick, sick of proud heart: you may call it

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: melancholy, if you will favour the man; but, by my

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: head, 'tis pride: but why, why? let him show us the

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: cause. A word, my lord.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Takes AGAMEMNON aside

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: What moves Ajax thus to bay at him?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Achilles hath inveigled his fool from him.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Who, Thersites?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Then will Ajax lack matter, if he have lost his argument.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: No, you see, he is his argument that has his

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: argument, Achilles.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: All the better; their fraction is more our wish than

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: their faction: but it was a strong composure a fool

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: could disunite.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The amity that wisdom knits not, folly may easily

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: untie. Here comes Patroclus.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Re-enter PATROCLUS

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: No Achilles with him.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The elephant hath joints, but none for courtesy:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: his legs are legs for necessity, not for flexure.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Achilles bids me say, he is much sorry,

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: If any thing more than your sport and pleasure

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Did move your greatness and this noble state

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: To call upon him; he hopes it is no other

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: But for your health and your digestion sake,

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: And after-dinner's breath.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Hear you, Patroclus:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We are too well acquainted with these answers:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: But his evasion, wing'd thus swift with scorn,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Cannot outfly our apprehensions.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Much attribute he hath, and much the reason

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Why we ascribe it to him; yet all his virtues,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Not virtuously on his own part beheld,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Do in our eyes begin to lose their gloss,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Yea, like fair fruit in an unwholesome dish,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Are like to rot untasted. Go and tell him,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We come to speak with him; and you shall not sin,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: If you do say we think him over-proud

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: And under-honest, in self-assumption greater

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Than in the note of judgment; and worthier

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: than himself

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Here tend the savage strangeness he puts on,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Disguise the holy strength of their command,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: And underwrite in an observing kind

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: His humorous predominance; yea, watch

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: His pettish lunes, his ebbs, his flows, as if

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: The passage and whole carriage of this action

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Rode on his tide. Go tell him this, and add,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: That if he overhold his price so much,

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We'll none of him; but let him, like an engine

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Not portable, lie under this report:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: 'Bring action hither, this cannot go to war:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: A stirring dwarf we do allowance give

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Before a sleeping giant.' Tell him so.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: I shall; and bring his answer presently.

speaker: PATROCLUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: In second voice we'll not be satisfied;

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: We come to speak with him. Ulysses, enter you.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Exit ULYSSES

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: What is he more than another?

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: No more than what he thinks he is.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Is he so much? Do you not think he thinks himself a

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: better man than I am?

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: No question.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Will you subscribe his thought, and say he is?

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: No, noble Ajax; you are as strong, as valiant, as

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: wise, no less noble, much more gentle, and altogether

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: more tractable.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Why should a man be proud? How doth pride grow? I

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: know not what pride is.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Your mind is the clearer, Ajax, and your virtues the

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: fairer. He that is proud eats up himself: pride is

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: his own glass, his own trumpet, his own chronicle;

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: and whatever praises itself but in the deed, devours

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: the deed in the praise.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: I do hate a proud man, as I hate the engendering of toads.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Yet he loves himself: is't not strange?

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Aside

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Re-enter ULYSSES

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Achilles will not to the field to-morrow.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: What's his excuse?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He doth rely on none,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: But carries on the stream of his dispose

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Without observance or respect of any,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: In will peculiar and in self-admission.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Why will he not upon our fair request

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Untent his person and share the air with us?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Things small as nothing, for request's sake only,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He makes important: possess'd he is with greatness,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And speaks not to himself but with a pride

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That quarrels at self-breath: imagined worth

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Holds in his blood such swoln and hot discourse

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That 'twixt his mental and his active parts

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Kingdom'd Achilles in commotion rages

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And batters down himself: what should I say?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He is so plaguy proud that the death-tokens of it

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Cry 'No recovery.'

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Let Ajax go to him.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Dear lord, go you and greet him in his tent:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: 'Tis said he holds you well, and will be led

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: At your request a little from himself.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: O Agamemnon, let it not be so!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: We'll consecrate the steps that Ajax makes

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: When they go from Achilles: shall the proud lord

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That bastes his arrogance with his own seam

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And never suffers matter of the world

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Enter his thoughts, save such as do revolve

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And ruminate himself, shall he be worshipp'd

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Of that we hold an idol more than he?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: No, this thrice worthy and right valiant lord

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Must not so stale his palm, nobly acquired;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Nor, by my will, assubjugate his merit,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As amply titled as Achilles is,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: By going to Achilles:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: That were to enlard his fat already pride

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And add more coals to Cancer when he burns

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: With entertaining great Hyperion.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: This lord go to him! Jupiter forbid,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And say in thunder 'Achilles go to him.'

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: [Aside to DIOMEDES]  O, this is well; he rubs the

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: vein of him.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: [Aside to NESTOR]  And how his silence drinks up

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: this applause!

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: If I go to him, with my armed fist I'll pash him o'er the face.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: O, no, you shall not go.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: An a' be proud with me, I'll pheeze his pride:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Let me go to him.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Not for the worth that hangs upon our quarrel.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: A paltry, insolent fellow!

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: How he describes himself!

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Can he not be sociable?

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: The raven chides blackness.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: I'll let his humours blood.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: He will be the physician that should be the patient.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: An all men were o' my mind,--

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Wit would be out of fashion.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: A' should not bear it so, a' should eat swords first:

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: shall pride carry it?

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: An 'twould, you'ld carry half.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: A' would have ten shares.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: I will knead him; I'll make him supple.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: He's not yet through warm: force him with praises:

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: pour in, pour in; his ambition is dry.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: [To AGAMEMNON]  My lord, you feed too much on this dislike.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Our noble general, do not do so.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: You must prepare to fight without Achilles.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Why, 'tis this naming of him does him harm.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Here is a man--but 'tis before his face;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: I will be silent.

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Wherefore should you so?

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: He is not emulous, as Achilles is.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Know the whole world, he is as valiant.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: A whoreson dog, that shall pelter thus with us!

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Would he were a Trojan!

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: What a vice were it in Ajax now,--

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: If he were proud,--

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Or covetous of praise,--

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Ay, or surly borne,--

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Or strange, or self-affected!

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Thank the heavens, lord, thou art of sweet composure;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Praise him that got thee, she that gave thee suck:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Famed be thy tutor, and thy parts of nature

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Thrice famed, beyond all erudition:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: But he that disciplined thy arms to fight,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Let Mars divide eternity in twain,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And give him half: and, for thy vigour,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Bull-bearing Milo his addition yield

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To sinewy Ajax. I will not praise thy wisdom,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Which, like a bourn, a pale, a shore, confines

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Thy spacious and dilated parts: here's Nestor;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Instructed by the antiquary times,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: He must, he is, he cannot but be wise:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Put pardon, father Nestor, were your days

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: As green as Ajax' and your brain so temper'd,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: You should not have the eminence of him,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: But be as Ajax.

speaker: AJAX
text_entry: Shall I call you father?

speaker: NESTOR
text_entry: Ay, my good son.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Be ruled by him, Lord Ajax.

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: There is no tarrying here; the hart Achilles

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Keeps thicket. Please it our great general

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: To call together all his state of war;

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: Fresh kings are come to Troy: to-morrow

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: We must with all our main of power stand fast:

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And here's a lord,--come knights from east to west,

speaker: ULYSSES
text_entry: And cull their flower, Ajax shall cope the best.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Go we to council. Let Achilles sleep:

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Light boats sail swift, though greater hulks draw deep.

speaker: AGAMEMNON
text_entry: Exeunt
